Early Access Review
								Difficult games fall into two catagories: Those that are challenging, and those that are frustrating.  This game, alas, falls into the later category.  My main issues:1.  There is no good way to control overheating in summer.  Especially when the 1200hp Zombie is fighting them all in the middle of the day.  They stand and fight and die of heat exhaustion.  2.  The monster difficulty seems to grow exponentially.  On day 3, it's not uncommon for 700 to 800 hp monsters to waltz through my defences.  By day 5, they're close to 1500 hp.  I've never made it past that point, so I can only guess how vastly overpowered they become.3.  The inability to rotate buildings.  When most buildings are rectangles, it helps to compact your base.4.  The monsters just break through the walls, rather than going through the killing maze.  It's impossible to concentrate enough fire when they come through whatever wall is inconvenient to them.5.  What it boils down to is a tower defence game with a focus on the infrastructure behind the towers.  It's not what I was expecting from a village simulator.  I'm not a big fan of tower defence games to begin with, so this was a rather sad realization.6.  There are no guards or soldiers.  You get golems who can't stand a chance against anything but a slime.  It would be nice to have soldiers who could sortie out and soften up the monsters.EDIT:I am changing my review to positive.  The developer is prompt and courteous, and there seems to be a lot of changes in the works.  I kind of forgot the game is in alpha still because of how well it looks and, aside from the frustrations mentioned above, works.  I suppose, deep down, I'm afraid of getting burned by another Towns.  Thankfully, I don't think that's a concern here.  I look forward to the continued development of what portends to be a great time waster.

Early Access Review
								I like RPC, I really do. At the moment there's not much to it, however. If you like building villages, micro-managing resources and villager needs, RPC has a few good things going for it, but there's also a lot holding it back, including the word "castle".It's tough; really tough actually, and if you screw up, you pretty much have to make a new profile to try again, you can't just pick a different area on the map. This is a minor annoyance given that you can easily screw yourself over, especially while just learning the game.I like that there's enemies to defend your castle against, but they -easily- overwhelm most defenses, and at the moment, the only way to defend is tower-defense-like mazes you have to build, where half of the towers are pretty much useless. I found the fire towers to draw way too much power to be useful and the rock towers near useless since they have to be out in the open,(can't be behind walls) right where enemies can easily swarm it, making the point of it, to roll a rock down a line of enemies, useless. Real castles didn't work this way, they had gates, moats, walls you could sit on and shoot down, etc. I really wish there was more "castle" in this game. There really isn't, it's more akin to Retro-Pixel Villages.It's a fun little game, I like the aesthetic, and I like most of the resource managment and crafting system, but I'm gonna wait and come back to it later when/if/hopefully they add more "castle" elements like walls with gates and such, I'm tired of making mazes and getting overwhelmed, and when more later-game content comes in. Very nice so far though! I will revisit and re-review it in the future.

Early Access Review
								A magnificent attention to detail went into the textures for this game! With several variations for each object or tile, nothing in the map looks quite like the copy-and-paste wireframe you usually expect to see in other 2D pixel games. Down to the last blade of grass, there seems to be a nice variety of different shades, shapes and directions each individual block displays - with every texture having a decorative secondary layer for its own material type. Complementing the game's surprisingly vibrant and lively textures is an amazing, hand-crafted lighting system ruled over by some of the other textures and objects, and a fully functional day-and-night cycle. Torches provide a light source, lava illuminates a small radius of land around it, and crystals glow in the dark like fireflies. Every wall and object has a dynamic and intricate reaction to which direction the sun is in relation to the world below (as well as other light sources), which changes gradually as the day cycle goes by. Even the water shines in the night as the moon reflects down on it! While this may not sound like much to most modern gamers, for a pixel-based game, the way this is handled is extremely impressive, and adds a clever illusion of 3D with a very nice shadow system. Even some of the world textures are crafted with certain curves around the edges and changes of width that add a realistic sense of direction and angle. This is most visible in the game's own main menu, with the stone-brick wall trim which boxes us in the game's window. The game currently is still in a very early alpha stage and offers no enemies or immediate dangers beyond the starvation of your villagers who wander around aimlessly like hilarious morons until you lay out the foundation for a town hall and send out vague and indirect orders for different resources - a feature true to its own advertisement. This game is definitely no standard RTS, as you have much less control over what happens within the world, instead treating the villagers like ants in an antfarm. You give them basic instructions and a general goal in life, and they immediately begin deciding amongst themselves who works where and who gathers or builds what. Villagers marry and house themselves independently (assuming there had already been homes built, by your command) and have their own unique set of attributes such as Strength and Dexterity, which increase depending on how hard they work or how long they travel. If they are over-worked or if a spouse dies, a villager will become extremely depressed, and lose the will and the energy to continue working at full capacity for a short period of time. Eventually, the villager will find relief in rest or another lover, and so will continue on with his or her life.  The lack of direct control over your villagers is a very welcome and unique change of flow from your average city-building sim, as it gives you a very relaxed and non-competitive or war-driven experience. While I'm sure more threats will be introduced further down the line, the general concept of the game so far is very interesting and humble. I personally have never seen a game concept quite like this, and despite my lack of interest in pixel-based games, I found this quite enjoyable. Even with its current lack of content. This is still a very early build, with a lot of features and content to be added as time goes by. As for right now though, in the state it's in at the time, it comes with a refreshing breath of life in the world of sandbox sims.  Where other games force linear and challenging objectives  or goals, this game's only real objective is survival, and determining how to best accomplish this, with strategy. The gameplay itself reminds me somewhat of Lemmings and Black & White, two gems from Lionhead Studios and Team17. One an objective-based RTS sim where you give general orders to minions in order to help them escape a maze, and the other a god-game where you do your best to keep a strong and stable economy and gain control over other villages. All in all, Retro-Pixel Castles comes with an /exceptionally/ nice soundtrack which really helps set the mood and clear the mind, and a surprising amount of detail and clarity in its world textures which promises a great deal of polish in the final product. The lighting and 3D-like illusions shown in 2D textures makes the game almost remind me a little of Don't Starve, with its ability to turn a simple 2D world into something more like a pop-out storybook. To know that all this comes from such a small dev team is very thrilling, and I would definitely like to see what direction this project takes in the future.

Early Access Review
OVERVIEWNote: Rise to Ruins is currently in Early Access. The version reviewed was InDev25d.Rise to Ruins is a village simulator with some god game elements, from indie developer Raymond Doerr. It was previously titled Retro-Pixel Castles.In Rise to Ruins, you're given a group of settlers with whom you have to found a village and survive for as long as possible. Like most games of this type, there's no real end goal -- or at least none that I'm aware of -- instead you tend to play until your village is wiped out (or nearly so) and then you start again and try to do better next time. The game includes seasonal climate changes and a day/night cycle, both of which present further complications and challenges, but which are great additions to the game.GraphicsThe game is played from a top-down overhead view, with characters (people and monsters) drawn from a three-quarter perspective to give them a bit more personality. You can adjust the zoom from a functional-but-not-quite-far-enough minimum, allowing you to see a fair bit of the surrounding area, up to a chunky-pixel maximum, where a single villager takes up a fair portion of the screen. At minimum zoom the game looks quite nice, with map tiles being well drawn, and characters looking like colourful ants. At maximum zoom the characters look a bit too blocky for my liking.There are no real graphics detail settings, though there are particle and shadow settings, and the obligatory windowed/full-screen options. (ProTip: Don't play in full screen; it's very buggy.) It's not a graphics-heavy game by any means, but it chugs along nicely even with a hundred or so villagers all going about their business.SoundMusic has a nice fantasy/mediaeval theme that suits the game well in my opinion. Sound effects are functional, but nothing special.GameplayRise to Ruins begins with an overhead map of the game's continent, from which you select a region in which you want to settle your first village. These locations differ in available resources and, I think, climate, so choose carefully. (You can found multiple villages in different regions, but you only have a limited pool of villagers, shared between them all.)After you've chosen a region the game takes you to the region map, from which you'll play the game proper. There's no real tutorial at the moment, but the game gives you some help in the form of pop-up tips. These are a bit lacking, though. For example, I had no food growth and no food, but nothing in any of the tips told me I should build anything until it was too late, and even then I didn't know the best place to build it. An in-game tutorial would really help; the youtube tutorial video notwithstanding. Still, although you should be able to work out the very basics pretty easily, it's a steep learning curve when things go wrong and you don't know why. The Steam Discussions are a useful resource.Anyway, you choose a section of promising looking land -- water, rocks, trees, and wild food, if you can find it, are all good -- and build a camp. That then lets you build other buildings, too, and before long you're harvesting resources and growing your camp into a little village community.As is common to many god games, you don't have any direct control over your people; you can assign them to tasks -- builder is the only one available to begin with, but as you build more buildings, more jobs become available -- and that's about it. To harvest resources you select and highlight them on the map, and your people are supposed to harvest as many as they need, and no more.You very quickly need to build up some basic infrastructure, including housing, food growth, water processing, and some rudimentary defences, the latter being required because you never know when a wandering monster might wander into your village and start attacking your people. Combat seems to be stacked against you, too; you don't have any really good 'troops' of your own, and the tower-defence style of defence doesn't quite seem to work: monsters bash through walls rather than being funnelled to your 'kill zone', and it's sometimes hard to even notice them in the first place, with no ability to automatically focus on important events.You also have a small collection of god powers, which you can use by spending your collected essence: another resource, but one that's harvested by you rather than your people. I was a little disappointed in these, as I'd been hoping for a bit more range and depth to them, but what's there is useful and well thought out. I guess it would be fair to say they're more like Populous than Populous II.Rise to Ruins has been in Early Access for about two-and-a-half years, so you'd be forgiven for worrying that it had been abandoned. It definitely hasn't, though: the developer releases regular updates and is active in the Steam Community for the game. As you'd expect from an EA title, though, Rise to Ruins does have some bugs. My first hour with the game consisted of about 15 minutes of playtime, followed by 45 minutes of trying to recover from a crash. The game just wouldn't restart and instead sat there spinning Windows' blue wheel of doom until I killed it. I eventually manually edited the settings and turned off full-screen mode and after that it worked again.You'll encounter minor issues, too. Even with many idle people I found that building would often stop due to no resources being available, so the automatic resource harvesting seems to need a bit of adjustment. The UI is a bit wonky and controls aren't what I would choose, either, but they're functional, and the developer has stated that he reworks the UI every now and then, so what's here now may not be here forever. There's a big message reminding you to press the middle mouse button to cancel whenever you're in the middle of an action, such as designating resources or using god powers; it's lucky it's there, since middle mouse button to cancel is not intuitive at all.PROS AND CONSPros:+ Detailed and in-depth simulation; there's a lot to learn+ Different game modes from casual and explorative (sandbox) to VERY challenging (survival)+ Solid design with a dedicated developer+ Nice music, nice graphics at lower zoom levelsCons:- No proper tutorial, making for a very steep learning curve- Some bad bugs, especially in full screen- Some awkward controls- Combat isn't that greatCONCLUSIONI've only just begun to learn some of Rise to Ruin's intricacies, but I can see there's a lot here. It still has plenty of rough edges, but the developer releases frequent updates and is always responding to comments.If you have the time to invest in it, I expect you'll find Rise to Ruins very rewarding.Super SaveSaveSave for Later - 70 / 100PauseQuitRage QuitNote: I received this game for free for review purposes. Early Access Review
								I'll do my best to keep this review updated as the game progresses. (2/1/2015 - Current Ver: Indev12c, Indev13 roadmap announced)I'm recommending this, but I have a few caveats before I get to my review. If you're expecting a game that is 100% or even 80% realized as of (2/1/2015) then you probably haven't had much experience with Early Access and you probably shouldn't buy this game YET. Or if the feedback-and-support thing doesn't appeal to you, the $15 pricetag might seem a bit steep. Even then, if you're afraid of vaporware (I know I am), read the store page thoroughly as Ray (the dev) has done his best to put your fears to rest. Still mistrusting? I'm here for ya, or go to the website (or any of the links provided on the store page) and form your own opinion Official Website[retropixelcastles.com](main website link on store page seems to be broken). I know it's some extra effort than you would normally spend, but Ray is very active on his official forums and he will certainly answer any questions regarding his vision and the current state of development before you make a decision on purchasing.That said, I feel with the risk of vaporware and rushed products, opinion on the dev in an Early Access review is just as important as the game itself and I'll address that with my opinion first. If you don't care, scroll down and read the game portion. I'll remove this once the game goes Full-Access.Review of Indie Developer Raymond Doerr(scroll down for game review)This man has earned my respect among a slew of Indie "Developers" (Opportunists) that started with Minecraft (Jeb had made a lot of promises like our Alpha/Beta contributions entitling us to free Xbox copies before it was so popular -- didn't happen) and continues to this day with practically every Early Access game on Steam. So much so I've learned to type the simple little word "dev" with a bit of spite in my mental voice. Ray is not that man. While this is an opinion, and one I cannot garuntee in the future, I very strongly feel this way. Just talk to him, you'll see.Little things like his naming of his updates Indev12-13 versus 0.12.02 (this is no race to the magic 1.0! it's just a progress report) to his efforts to ask/require your input and support when so many people are so rightfully afraid to give it through an otherwise legitimate manner set him apart.When I was younger, Independently-Developed games were practically non-existent. To be a Beta Tester, you had to send in a resume to a big name company and you had to be hired, it was a job, before your voice ever mattered in the gaming world. I have a job so that's not an option, but through Ray and his SixtyGig Games (and with $15) my voice is heard. That is what Early Access, Independently-Developed games, and Raymond Doerr is all about.(had to be cut short for the actual game review, the lengthy praise is warranted though, I f-ing hate vaporware and the only way around it are honest reviews)Review of Retro-Pixel CastlesCurrent Version: Indev12c(Pro/Con lists are not my style, hope you like to read)InfluencesOn the Steam Store Page, the game is marked as having several noticable influences, but in its current version, I mainly  agree with three of them, and I'll try to break them down.Dwarf Fortress: This is the most obvious influence in my opinion (and also the closest game to ever touch upon what I want in a DF-like game), You have practically zero control over your villagers. You can place buildings to be constructed when your villagers get to it (although in a generally predictable manner), set resource harvesting tasks, and assign free (random) villagers to work at certain buildings. That's about it for control right now, and where most of the DF influence stops. P.S. "Losing is Fun!" theme is well-intact in Retro-Pixel Castles.Banished: You start the game on whatever map you choose with nothing but a bunch of villagers and are free to choose where you place your Village Center (required before you can build anything else and serves as radial zone for where you can place other buildings at first, so choose wisely!), unless someone (or you!) has made a map where the Village Center was already placed (you only get one, this ain't no 4x). Also, when you build your first farm, you have to collect wild food (carrots only, so far) before they can start growing them in the farm (this is a one-time deal, a working farm can populate a new one). While it is ultimately a village sim and has buildings, food/energy requirements, I'd end the tracable influences to Banished there.Tower Defense: This is a big one, as it encompasses the actual challenge of the game. I spend most of my time on Peaceful, because I'm a casual grow-and-love city builder type gamer, but this is one of the rare few games where I'll switch off peaceful and play the regular game because A) Peaceful at this stage is -super- low on content and extremely easy being locked on Day 1 difficulty (you really only need/will ever use 2-4 of the available building types) B) Instead of devoting my city to raising a military, in Tower Defense style, your buildings do most of the work for you (your villagers will fight mobs, dumbly, and you will lose a lot of them, but that's the point! "Losing is Fun!"). Also, currently, you get to have one save, per mode, per map, per profile (you really only need one profile, unless you have a family or RL friends -scoff-) so I can come back to my peaceful cities when I want. So far (more buildings planned in the next update, expect this to change), the only offensive building is a Fire Tower (you can also build walls for defense/mob funneling) which will TD-style automatically fire at mobs close enough. All living things die in a burst of pixelated blood and green "essence" which serves as mana/power for your Fire Tower (and an Essence Collector, which is essentially a battery for the Fire Tower). Every day that you survive, the rate that mobs appear increases, and so the difficulty.Most of the game and its mechanics are covered above.Atmosphere:Pixels!: At this point, you either love pixel-art or hate it. If you love it, this game does it very well. There's even an option to smooth out some of the pixel animation like essence flowing to an Essence Collector/Fire Tower(which looks gorgeous and well-fantasy-themed even for pixels), but I like pixels so I haven't even bothered. I'll edit this next time I go into the game and look (which may not be til the next update).Music/Sound: Music is a nice, calming fantasy-like tune that fits well into the pixel-art world. I've never had to turn it down or off after several hours, but that's really all I have to say about it, as I tend to not notice game music anyways. Sounds come mainly from birth/death of villagers and are just a quick happy or sad tune that fits with the music-style.Maps:You can make your own maps! Saved in whatever, and however many, folders you'd like. Ray is currently not very focused on (or very impressive at - sorry man) making maps for the game himself, which brings me to a special point.If you buy Early Access and you make a good map and post it on his forum, Ray may add your map to the game before final release! This is, as far as it stands now, an Early-Access-Only feature. I've seen those threads pop up, and I've seen maps get added, and updated. Be a real contributor to the game!Maps are 1-z level (no digging down DF fans, these are humans!) but give a vague impression of depth as dense resources appear "taller" than their regular counterparts and is a nice touch to the aesthetic without complicated mechanics needed.Currently, Ray is experimenting with map size in an effort to reduce code/program efficiency, so if you get in now, there might be changes.

								"Retro-Pixel Castles" is a village simulator that is a bit rogue-like in the sense that you'll be trying to grow and prosper your town for as long as you can before your little uncontrollable villagers succumb to whatever hellish death awaits them.  In short, you can't win...though you can learn from your mistakes and see how long you can last the next time out.  It's got a while before release (a year or more), so there's still a lot of work to be done.  I myself see a lot of potential here, though it's all very basic right now.  The lack of a save feature is probably my biggest gripe with the current build, though a fast-forward button would admittedly be nice too.  Still, you can browse the Internet and the like while you play as it is able to run in the background.  With no price increase planned at launch, you can safely watch this one until you feel comfortable with buying it.

Early Access Review
IntroductionRetro-Pixel Castles: The Godlike Village Simulator is developed by Raymond Doerr and published by SixtyGig Games. While still in Early Access, it shows promise and it is by no means a small feat, given the fact that this title is the dev team’s first Steam project. GameplayEven though there’s not one playthrough similar to another, Retro-Pixel Castles does offer the necessary tools and assets needed for both the survival as well as thriving of the miniaturized society being simulated in our case. If there’s one good thing that comes out of such random scenarios, is that boredom has a hard time setting in provided you are familiar with the god game formula. It’s definitely harder than economic simulators/city builders that are more abundent on Steam. You have to constantly keep an eye on your villagers and protect them from natural hazards and foes, while also having a clear expansion pattern as the resources on the maps do encourage some planning ahead. The game’s tutorial felt a bit thin on content and tips, but there’s still room for improvement. While it may seem rather difficult for beginners, once you know how to prioritize your building projects and manage the initial small population, things become much easier. The audio-visual department is the one that might require some more tinkering from the developer’s side. Music and soud effects seem quite repetitive while the fonts have a slight resolution problem. Zooming in or out would be nice touches as the pixelated graphics don’t bother me at all. In such a game which features enough gameplay complexity as it is, the eye candy can be safely overlooked. Pros+ Randomly generated assets+ Freedom of choice with an open-ended storylineCons- No Achievements or Trading Cards- Still in Early Access- Sounds are repetitiveResult / Final thoughtsIt is truly unfortunate that we have such a limited selection of god games on the Steam Store, but we must make do with what can be found already as well as the newly released ones. Retro-Pixel Castles is just such a title, both promising and with a charm of its own. More than enough to stand out and not be considered just a shout-out to an often neglected genre.Rating 7/10 This review was submitted for Elite Giveaways, check us out for more reviews ranging from Indie games to AAA titles.

Early Access Review
								Edited on Jan 29 2015So this game has been updated, and i've been asked to check the game out again since there is now more content, and this does TECHNICALLY qualify as an early version of the game, rather than simply being a tech demo as it originally was, dumped on steam with no warning that the game wasn't practically playable any more than starcraft 2 with only command centers and scv's would be.But i'm not impressed. My problems with this game comes down to  - Terrible "village management" - Sketchy bussiness practice, not necessarily malignant, but the dev is inexperienced and it shows - Lack of direction - There is no way to make interesting maps (All current ones are garbage) - Even at 10€ the game is heavily overpricedI don't want to go into little bugs and irritants, although they are not in short supply, this is early access and these are expected, but the above problems aren't something you can fix with a little patch, they require major reworkings of the game or the way the development operates.By far the biggest issue here is the way new villagers are aquired; the game borrows the double dumbass approach of towns where you will only reproduce if your people are happy AND your people will only be happy if they aren't doing anything. I really didn't want to add this sentence but if you look in the comments for this review it's obvious i'm going to get called on it if i don't so yes, technically you CAN aquire new citizens even at 0 happiness, but the odds of that happening are so abysmally low, i've played 4 games now and i've seen 1 new person appear at <25 happiness, so it doesn't matter.This is made far worse by the game's approach to combat. I expect combat to change a lot as new features are planned for it, but it is still taking the approach of high volatility combat; you're going to lose people defending your home. Compare this to Towns and Dwarf Fortress; in towns you also have this stupid villager approach to population growth, but you're very unlikely to lose people in combat, so it doesn't completely shut down your village even if you're frequently in combat. Dwarf fortress has frequent, massive genocides with scores of dead characters, but population growth is tied to the value of all items your fort owns, and looting enemies gives you lots of weapons, armor and clothes of good value, so you typically get lots of new migrants coming in to refill the ranks of your military.This game has you attacked about every 30 seconds right now, there is practically no breathing room, and it starts immediately. The game seems more like an RTS than a village sim, but with an extremely slow process of replenishing your forces. This could work in the same ways as custom maps for starcraft and warcraft have done, which was awesome, but when you can't expand your population you're just stuck, unable to do anything.Tying happiness to idling is another total failure for the game, especially with the constant aggression. You basically turn the whole game into ballancing workload vs free time; too little workload and you won't be able to build the defenses, too much workload and you never get enough people. This could work as a component to the game, but it just becomes the sole focus, and all you end up doing is unassigning and reassigning people in a neverending circle of tedius micromanagement.Speaking of tedius micromanagement, the villagers are terrible at carrying out tasks efficiently. If you order too many houses/defenses/farms (read: more than 2) they'll start building the first house, then when it's halfway done, they apparently switch to the next, with just a few people working on the first. The result is a collage of unfinished structures littering your town, and if you're building defenses while they're being attacked, the builders will drop their materials to fight, then carry them of to the wrong building, leaving a single unfinished tower for up to 20 minutes was the worst i had, with the little idiots running back to pick up their wood, then drop it as a zombie got close, run over to punch the zombie, then pick up the wood and haul it to another tower under construction. (I queued 4 towers, silly me)This isn't really a big issue to work around, just don't queue up constructions, right? Sure, but this is more micromanagement on top of giving builders their mandatory vacation time, and on top of the next issue:Villagers apparently gather resources from completely random places. This means if you're building something in one place and you assign them to gather wood/rocks nearby, they'll gather it there, but if you then build the next building somewhere else (Why would anyone want to keep their farms and defenses seperate...?) you have to unassign where to gather resources, or the idiots will run halfway across the map to chop down a tree, instead of the one assigned right next to them. All this combined means you don't spend your time organizing defenses, planning your town or anything you'd expect from this game, you're just babysitting these idiotic villagers; go chop here, don't chop there, don't be a builder, don't mine there, mine here, be a builder, don't be a farmer, etc. etc. and this is what the game is; it takes hours to build anything because of this nonsense, and you need to leave the game running without building anything to get new villagers.The other major issue with this as a village sim is that there are no different resources; just food and construction materials. Wood and stone are just different colours; no buildings/tools/tech needed for extraction, take the same time, trees don't regrow, what's the point?The game's bussiness practice also smells bad. The game was initially kickstarted successfully, and IMMEDIATELY after that it was dumped on early access, despite being nothing more than an abysmal tech demo; no combat, just farms and houses forever; 30 minutes and the game ran out of things to do. My problem with this is how eager the dev is for cash. Why wasn't the kickstarter enough to at least make a functional game before throwing it out here? He'll happily charge full price for a tech demo, and the "game" has even been on sale. I hate old sayings, but "Don't sell the skin before shooting the bear" seems apt for once.The other problem the dev has is the game's lack of focus. This game is NOT on early access to get feedback, because there are so many features missing it's practically impossible to give any worthwhile feedback. What the dev seems to want is ideas for where to take his game, and early access is a terrible place for that. Maybe you want a village sim and this turns into an RTS? Well then, jokes on you. It's impossible to satisfy everyone, but you're still charging them for it. Like i wrote at first, the game has elements of an RTS and a village sim as the dev advertises both on the store page and here: http://retropixelcastles.com/index.php?/page/key_features.html but they don't work together. You can't have the volatility of an RTS combined with the slow growth of a village sim; one has to dominate. The game also touts this "inevitable failure" part, as if it has any benefit; If you're building a village you want to see it grow and expand; what's the point of that if the village doesn't matter and you're just playing for high score? I don't mind the "see how long you can last" thing, but its fun in an RTS, where you build things only because of their immediate value to your survival, not in a village sim. Apparently we're supposed to unlock stuff after we die, because grinding for necessary unlocks is everyone's favorite thing about videogames.The game also claims to be "unique" which is nonsense; stronghold and majesty has done "defend and grow village" over a decade ago, and MUCH better. TL;DR: This is an RTS where all you can build is farms, houses and towers, and you can't control or replenish your units.

Early Access Review
								The sole developer, Raymond Doerr, is offering up a first class Early Access experience. He seems to be astoundingly active, quickly answering messages on twitter, Steam and the dedicated official game site, which is itself well maintained with an artful attention to detail. Updates come thick and fast, with a casual little suggestion of mine turning up in a patch a day later. Very gratifying! You can really see how determined he is to make this something great, accounting for every piece of feedback. So I'm fully reassured that, even though it's almost two year's since the successful Kickstarter, Retro-Pixel Castles will eventually reach a proper, full release, however long is need to make it a really great gaming experience.As of the current version, inDev22e, I'd say that the game alone is only just about worth it's price tag. There are a couple of nights worth of obsessive play in there, building out your village and defense setup, provided you have a modicum of patience to get into it. After failing initially, I personally watched the handily linked 'tutorial' video, to get the gist of a few basics. The in-game tips were very helpful too. But having figured out how to survive the initial onslaught, the excitement does trail off... The transition to starting a new village map is currently a little rough and without any campaign mechanism in place yet there's no particular motivation to go through the motions more than a couple times.However, it looks like the game's meta is due to change with the upcoming monthly major update and there are a lot of promising additions lined up. Really looking forwards to the future of this project. :-)Bear in mind that while this game is the same genre as Rimworld, it's pretty distinct from it - it's more like supervising a colony of ants, with no capacity or need to micromanage each little person. I feel the villager AI works pretty well, but it's best not to worry too much about the fine detail, just plan out your build strategy and keep an eye on those monsters. Also, there's a significant (and hopefully growing) tower defense aspect to the play, with it being possible to build little mazes for enemies to path through while getting shot. Quite a novel marriage of two of my favorite, most addictive game genres!Also be warned that the game can run a little choppily under certain circumstances, but is getting better optimized with each update and refinements are also due that should help avoid overly demanding conditions. Likewise I experienced a couple of crashes initially, but the frequent auto-save meant I never lost any progress and I've been unable to replicate the problem after recent updates. Continuous improvement.

Early Access Review
								Early Access Review:It took me a couple sittings before the game finally reeled me in, but boy has it given me that "one more turn" feel like Civ or Empire Earth. tl;dr at the bottom.So what is Retro-Pixel Castles?Right now it's basically a sandbox survival village building / god simulation game. As it's Early Access the content is currently limited, but there is enough to get a good idea of how great this game could be should it continue to go the direction it is currently being developed.What do you do?You can build a village, collect resources, expand your population, defend your land from monsters that attack at night, and then expand your control beyond the current map and export units/resources to "Limbo" where you can access them on other maps as part of the World Map system.What can't you do (yet)?Currently there are no animals, as noted by the dev. Building diversity is also very limited; you can see one or two variations of defensive buildings that use each resource type, there is essentially only one gathering building for each type of resource (wood, stone, and crystal), only one resource "refining" building for each type of resource, inventory management is a bit awkward--no ability to to prioritize what resources get stored in large storage buildings. Also magic buildings are limited to a portal to Limbo, an essence collecter (used to power magic defense structures), and a crystal motivator (regenerates your natural crystal deposits so they can be harvested sooner.), and a few defensive buildings.There is also currently only one playable race/faction. I would love to see different races / tribes that have alternate methods of collecting resources and different technologies/structures. As someone who grew up with Warcraft 2 and 3, I really fell in love with the base building. (I loved how the Undead didn't have to travel to collect gold, and how the Night Elves could collect wood without destroying trees, thus allowing forests to exist as walls where-as the Humans/Orcs eventually destroy every resource in their path to find each other.)Music is simple and satisfying, but I think it could use more variety as with most of the rest of the game.I hope the dev keeps on improving this game because I'm hooked, I want to see more but I'm afraid even when I expand to my second base there won't be anything but new terrain to see.tl;dr:This game is a fun mix of Dwarf Fortress and Warcraft 2/3. The graphics are colorful and bright. You can build a maze of walls for the monsters to run through turning it in to a real survival tower defense. I recommend it to anyone who likes retro village building.

The dev has already expressed he has no plans to include a 2x/3x speed option like in games such as Banished or RimWorld, however he will be including a Haste spell to speed your workers up. From what I can tell, this spell will really only be truly useful in the very first 2 or 3 days, because after that you will want to save your mana to blow up enemy spawns. So I don't think that the Haste spell will really solve much. The dev has stated higher speeds would be unnecessary because of the pace of the game, but I find myself with tons of downtime at every stage of the game. If it is a problem of implementation, I can understand, but I see no reason why an optional 2x or 3x speed button shouldn't be added.-Difficulty does not continue to scale. Now that I've done a few runs and I have a strategy for early-mid game, I'm completely ironclad and unstoppable by around day 11. More enemies will probably need to be added (remember you can always do resizes/recolors of existing sprites, nobody gets too upset about that as long as it's not rampant) that can add to more of a late game challenge.-Defense is pretty easy. All you need to do is make a large perimeter for your base and include a single choke point. Because of the enemy AI, they will walk across the entire map just to get to that choke point. I would recommend adding a certain distance threshold for enemies so that if they have to walk a certain distance to get around a wall, they will instead attack the nearest wall. This will force players to maintain multiple points of defense instead of one easily defended chokepoint.Misc suggestions:Quarries like in Banished - on rock floor areas, maybe you could add a building that allows villagers to mine a set amount of rock and iron from a 10x10 spot or however large you'd deem it. 								This game is very well made. Even though it´s still in development, it looks very promising.It´s a combination of a management game and a godgame, where you have to build, maintain and protect your own village(s). And those two genres have been merged together very well in this game.I recently bought it as I saw it in the store and it caught my attention. It looked like a simple management game, indie style. I have played Banished before, and it looks a bit like it, but this game has it's own characteristics as well. You have an "influence bar", which acts as a mana bar. With this influence, you can cast godly spells to improve land, fireball land/enemies/enemy buildings and much more.The game itself is very simple: You start with a global map with a couple of locations where you can start your first village. When you've chosen your location, you can start building! But you have to be fast. Just like other games, the night is very dangerous. The first night will remail calm, but the second night things go down... quickly.The game has a season mechanic. You start in the spring, the easiest of all 4 seasons as food grows the quickest in this season. You have to stockpile food to make sure you can get through the summer, where food growth is significantly slower. The autumn is the second best season, where you can recover from the summer. Though not optimal, it's still good enough to re-establish your food stockpile, as the next season is the harshest: winter. Food growth is almost at a halt, so you better have some food stored. However, with your godly abilities you can grab food from over the map and drop it in the village, to make sure you'll get through winter... if you even get there.Because when playing the regular game, survival mode, so-called "graveyards" and "slime spawns" spawn quite often, spawning many enemies. Eventually a lot of the map is covered with these graveyards and when the night comes, they can assault your village. If you haven't prepared your defences before that happens, it's pretty much over (RIP me :( ).But if you want to take it easy, there is also a peaceful mode, where almost no enemies spawn. It's a good way to learn the mechanics, as it's way more forgiving if you are a bit slow. If you don't know how to play the game at first, at the main menu there's a button which redirects you to a youtube video, explaining some of the basic mechanics of the game. It's quite helpful. You'll get tips on how to make your defences as good as possible and how different defensive towers work.It has some performence issues (at least for me) when autosaving, where your screen freezes for the duration. It isn't that bad, its usually for less than a second. There isn't however a way to decrease graphics so you have to play with a lot of particles all the time. And it's a lot, because there has been a lot of attention to details, which I absolutely love.The soundtrack is cute and athmospheric. It makes this game even more cute than it already is. That, which the sometimes corky and sometimes sarcastic pop-ups when you lose a villager or at the splashart of the main menu, makes it a very cute product over all.I'd give this an 8/10. It's very cute, it shows potential. However, it is a bit repetitive as you cannot develop a lot with for example a tech-tree or something. It's more like when you can process your wood and stone, you can basically build everything, which makes it somewhat less exciting rather quick. Yet it's a good game to kill some time with. You'll fall in love with the cuteness!

Early Access Review
								So I picked up RPC a couple of days ago, having kept an eye on it several years back on TIGSource, and I have to say that this game is one of the best I've played in a long long time. Combining my two favourite genres, TD and RTS with a pinch of Roller Coaster Tycoon, I have so far had an absolute blast. The game starts you on an island world map with the choice of your settling point - You can even go in and look at the maps first before setting up. Once you do that, you've got to balance the livelihoods of your population whilst being besieged by armies of monsters. You begin by gathering the basics - Food and Wood, but over time becoming accustomed with a diverse collection of structures and materials. Production lines form, your civilisation grows, squeezing in between valleys and digging into the safety of bedrock, rather than risking expanding outwards. In turn, beyond your bastions, holes open in the ground in increasing number as more enemies spill onto the map, slowly colouring the minimap red. The gameplay remains perfectly in flow with a fluctuating day/night cycle and on top of which 4 seasons that constantly mix up gameplay with various weather and effects on your settlement. You really have to stock up for winter (And the first year I massively over prepared, but better safe than sorry!) HINT - MAKE AS MANY FARMS AS YOU CAN - 28 farmers was a sustainable number for me (Whilst enriching wild food collections at the same time!).Most tower defences suffer from the same issue over time that they become tedious as you perfect your strategy. The twist that has hooked me for RPC is you have the option to send units to "limbo", essentially a menu screen where you can dish out your settlers to a variety of different lands on the map. I spent an hour just surveying the various maps and looking for potential choke points, weighing up the different collections of resources in each area, hesitant to send my villagers to certain doom after such a firm foothold on my first settlement.To add to this, I found myself grappling with the dilemmas of logging regulation (Do I flatten the forest to supplement my bow towers with arrows, but deal with the long grow back time and pathways destroying the treeline opened up) and I found myself picking single people to inhabit my future settlement to avoid breaking up my many many married couples (170 villagers so far!) Another fantastic mechanic is the line of sight for defences - Punishing players who box themselves in by preventing them from expanding beyond their walls. There were many times where I'd tear down a couple of the inner walls to frantically assemble some lines of trenches further forwards whilst fighting off hordes of monsters then patch my defences back up before nightfall. It puts a lot more risk in expansion and forces you to avoid greediness.The game has such depth that I've sunk over half a day into the Retro Pixel Castles over the weekend. It's just such a good game! I can't put it any simpler than that, haven't felt so transfixed about a strategy game since I discovered Age of Empires 2. Admittedly, the lack of a built in tutorial is something that could do with addressing, but obviously with Early Access I'm sure it's something that'll come about in time. The video that was linked in the game did provide me with enough information to get started with, so thank you for providing that. Having said this, discovering the functions of the game over time has been quite satisfying in itself - I'm still unlocking the mysteries of essence!It's a bit of a far fetched request (Especially with the number of units and stuff going on at once, but I would adore a co-op mode for this. Either way, amazing work, and I look forward to any approaching updates for the project.

Edit (2/17): Review is quite outdated. A lot of dev work has happened. At this point, I have no intention of revisiting the game, but I did spend the time originally to play and review, so my review stands. Such can be a consequence of long development cycles, and releasing software early. ---I *love* citybuilders and population managers. I think Gnomoria and Banished are two of my most played games on Steam with about 60 and 30 hours respectively. I put about 40 hours into Dwarf Fortress, and quite enjoyed it. While RPC desperately wants to be like these titles, it is very far off - in a bad way.First thing everybody should know is that there is no below-ground mining. Your world consists of a small-ish 'asteroid' that is one layer of ground thick, floating in space. There are frequent areas of the map that are just 'holes' where you can see the space behind the one-layer thick ground. I am certain that this strange mechanism is a result of limited money/resources/programming ability (idk), and was not intended. The allure of the games cited as inspiration (listed in first paragraph) was largely because you could take 'stuff' out of the ground and organize it above ground! When you take that away, I am significantly less interested.You cannot rotate buildings because it would take too much effort to redraw the images. I get it - prioritize developement, but this is something very basic that needs to be mentioned. It further hints at where this game is going. I would imagine these images could be done in a long weekend, am I right? I am not trying to be harsh, but potential buyers need to be aware of these things.These are the main two issues I have but there are a myriad of others such as map and individual person custimazation that I will not go into fully.There are also very few buildings at this point. Otherwise the music is quite good, and the artwork is pretty cool. This game probably was released on Early Access a bit too early. I got it for half price, and am fine with it because I want to try any and all citybuilders/population managers. To my Steam friends: if you haven't played Gnomoria or Banished yet, go for those! If you are like me and have exhausted those, this *might* quench your thirst for a bit.I don't believe any of the issues I put forth will be resolved (I mean its one guy working on this), but if they are, I will alter my review. Early Access Review
								This game is beautiful both mechanically and aesthetically, but at this point it is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hard. As soon as you start getting your perfect setup of buildings, you start to get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ I've only gotten to day 11, and thats with my last villager running with a couple hords gathered behind him. At about day 7, hordes of monsters will start to appear and there is no chance of survival. Its just depressing when you see them come in and hear the repeated sounds of slaughter. Even with three fire bolt towers constantly fueled at both of my entry points, monsters would still get through or just cause a massive heap of blood and flames that would consume anything that gets in it. It really sucks :( I know that its still in development, and I'm really excited for all of the stuff thats in the drawing board, but seriously this game becomes very frustrating at a certain point because there is nothing you can do about your villagers being brutally♥♥♥♥♥♥♥by the evil masses.Some suggestions: Building priority - some way to make sure that villagers will actually build the structures they set up. I've gotten very fed up with how they'll drop all the resources at the buliding, but then just forget about it even though its the only thing queued up to build. So a firebolt tower might be fully set with resources but won't actually be usable for a whole day or two because the villagers get distracted. Maybe make sure that as soon as the last one drops resources on the building, he starts to work on it. Specific land motivation - instead of just motivating the land in a general circle, maybe motivate certain resources. Its annoying having to either destroy or wait for my villagers to eventually chop down all the trees around small patches of food that I want to expand. If you try to expand without doing this, the forested area will just overrun the food, making it useless. Healing aura towers - monsters are quite overpowered and they outnumber your villagers easily. It'd be nice to have a slight but steady flow of health to them in certain areas. So you could set up a couple towers near the points of regular conflict and it would give them a little flow of health. This, or just making the healing aura more powerful would work. After about day 8 you need to drop a minimum of two healing auras to even make a dent in the damage that monsters do to your villagers. Thus using up a lot of your influence. Differentiating between friendlies and enemy health - maybe its just me, because i'm slightly colorblind, but I have a hard time telling the difference between the health bars when theres one of those massive heaps of blood and fire. It'd be cool if the health bars were drastically different in the color, or if a colorblind mode was added so you could have complementary colors, making them complete opposites. In conclusion, this game is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. When you get that flow of essence to your cullis gate, essence collectors, and firebolt towers... it just feels and looks amazing because theres all this power cycling through the map. Its a great way to show how everything is being fueled and refueled. After a successful night without any casualties, you feel like you did your godly job well. But its hard to get that job done because the people you rule are morons. Nevertheless, I would definitely recommend getting this game just so you can master your setup and understand whats most important. That way, once the devs to add in more complicated mechanics, you'll have all the basics completely down. Otherwise you'll just be thrown in later on with a LOT to learn. 9001/10 stars.

The sound track is quite good, although it isn't contextual: you can have an happy and reassuring track while the village is getting slaughtered. Particle effects are really cool and really add a lot to the presentation of the game.For now I absolutely cannot recommend this game in the current state. Early Access Review
								This is a fun base building game with zombie apocalypse overtones ;)  It's quite a challenging game, you really need to get started on building your food production and population from the first minute in order to survive for any decent time.  The position of your base is also critical.   It's important to try to use natural barriers (water, rocks, forests) as protection from zombies.  You can wall yourself in, but building even wooden fences can take a decent amount of resources and time. The game/developer seems to be of the opinion that losing should be "fun".  In other words it's a base builder game in the sprit of roguelikes such as Dwarf Fortress.  It's far easier to just pick up and play than most roguelikes, but if you don't like that style of game you may struggle with this.   Then again, if you haven't tried a similar game before, this would be a great intro. It's still in early access, so some of the building choices are a bit limited, but the developer seems to be adding features every few weeks which is great.  A few suggestions:An in game legend (easily accessible), with text explaining each of the small icons (emoticons) that appear above villagers and enemies would be handy.Needs a pause option.Maybe a bit more personality for the villagers and enemies would be nice.      This is a fun game and has the potential to be even better.

								Fun game if you enjoy the base building type of games.  (I do so I loved this game.)  For the most part, the gameplay and buildings are fairly straightforward.  There's definitely a learning curve to this game, though.  You will most likely have to start over at least a couple times. However, once you figure out your strategy and build a solid defence, the only struggle may be to have enough food during the winter.  As it's not finished yet, the game is still lacking, but I got 15 hours of good gameplay out of this game in it's current state. (Owned it for about a week as I write this).  I got it on sale for about $5 which is already well worth the price even without the fact that it will be updated.  My personal check for games is that it's, at least, satisfactory if it provides enough fun game play for one hour for every dollar it cost.  (So 3 hours/dollar so far is pretty good.)Quick tips if you want them:-Focus on a good defense ASAP. There's always room for improvement. Like dont even worry about having all the necessary housing.  You start in spring so the villagers can go a few nights outside.  Just build a good wall and defense towers (and ammo supply) ,  And use natural barriers to your adventure (forests and mountains.)-Don't spready yourself thin, too fast.  You start off with only so many people.  If you start building and employing all the different manufacturing and refining buildings, Your people will be spread thin among all them and it'll take forever to get more important things dones.-Edges to waters aren't as defensive as you think.  If you build a wall ending perpendicular to a body of water, monsters can still swim around the edge (Depending on what the quickest path is.)-Destroy spawners asap.  Use the Fireball power on any spawners that pop up (red squares on minimap).  You don't need to destroy them completely.  If you hit them, they'll slowly burn until they're destroyed (unless it starts to rain.)

And my personal opinion is, that in early access the product should not develop much from the content, but early access is for getting the flaws and small bugs out of the game. Not to actually develop it. I know that most game developers do it like this, which does not make it right. This particular game has a lot of potential, but currently i would not spend money on this.Its easy to only beef about something without giving advice on how i would like to see it develop. An example: Crepper world evermore. The first two parts were completely free and the third part came to steam without any early access thing and for a decent price. I personally experience it as a ripoff if the content of the game is developed in the (paid) early access since that is not what it is about. The early access is for fine-tuning the game and get some feedback from the comunity. Its about giving the game its last 5-10% not its last 50%. Early Access Review
								I remember buying this game while it was on sale since it was an early access game, but after sinking about 22 hours I regret not being able to pay the full price so that I can support the dev. That being said there are various pros and cons with RPCPros:- Graphics: This is a more personally pro for me, but I love the graphics on this game. The retro style is easy on the eyes and it's not hard to differentiate various things. That being said, if you expect crazy graphics from this game, this ain't the game for you- Controls: The controls are very easy to learn and get used to. Granted, I would like more hotkeys for various buildings/spells but I'm sure that they'll be implemented later on. Nonetheless, the controls are easy to learn and master- UI: The information that you need are so easily presented/accessible that you can see whatever you want either immediately or with a few clicks- AI: Except for a few hicks, the AI is pretty solid. Your workers will prioritize the buildings without fail and your guards will defend as best as they can. There really hasn't been a point where I've raged because of silly AICons:- Long Term Playability: The only real problem that I have with RPC is the lack of content in the late game. Once you're able to get to the late game harvesting buildings, there's really nothing else to do. However, I see this as a short term problem as this game is early access and from what I can gather from the dev's plans, this issue may be resolved- Difficulty: Similar to the problem above, once you get to the late game there really isn't anything that can threaten you. Is it impossible to fail, no. In fact, if there is a huge wave of monsters, you can and will fail through either poor management of spells or poor AI. However, as stated before this is mostly short term as this is early access and could be fixed through variety or increase in difficultyOverall: RPC is a great game, its retro style graphics and simplistic menus can lead towards hours of enjoyable gameplay. However, the lack of late game buildings/progression as well as the lack of difficulty past the initial phase of gameplay does bring the game down a lot. There has been quite some times where I would be bored since there was no new goal for me to reach or no new threat for me to fear. However, if these issues were to be fixed, this game would be extremely enjoyable and challenging.

I'll definitely come back in a few months and see how it developed.
